title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act within 3 days of enactment. The President must transmit a special message to Congress with a draft bill or joint resolution for each item of budget authority proposed to be rescinded. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act within 3 days of enactment. The President must transmit a special message to Congress with a draft bill or joint resolution for each item of budget authority proposed to be rescinded, specifying the details required by section 1012(a). The majority leader or minority leader of the House of Congress where the appropriation Act originated must introduce the draft bill or joint resolution within the second day of continuous session after receiving the special message. The majority leader or minority leader of the House of Congress must introduce the draft bill or joint resolution within the second day of continuous session after receiving the special message. If not introduced, any Member of that House may introduce the bill or joint resolution on the third day of continuous session. The bill or joint resolution shall be referred to the Committee on Appropriations and reported without substantive revision not later than the seventh day. The Committee on Appropriations must report the bill or joint resolution without substantive revision within the seventh day of continuous session after receiving a special message. If the committee fails to do so, they will be discharged, and the bill or joint resolution will be placed on the calendar for consideration. A vote on final passage must occur within the 10th calendar day of continuous session after the bill's introduction. A vote on final passage of a bill or joint resolution must occur within the 10th calendar day of continuous session after its introduction. If agreed to, the bill is engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day. A bill or joint resolution must be voted on for final passage within the 10th calendar day of continuous session after its introduction. If passed, it is transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day. Bills or joint resolutions referred to the House of Representatives or the Senate shall be sent to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it without substantive revision within seven days of receiving it. Committees failing to do so will be discharged from consideration of the bill. Committees failing to report a bill within the specified period will be automatically discharged from consideration, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for a vote. The final passage vote must occur within the 10th calendar day of continuous session after transmission to the other House of Congress. If passed, the engrossed bill is returned to the originating House for further action. The engrossed bill or joint resolution must be returned to the originating House by the Clerk of the House of Representatives or the Secretary of the Senate. Motion to proceed to consideration of a bill under this section in the House is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on a bill under this section in the House is limited to 4 hours. Debate in the House on a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. Appeals from decisions of the Chair regarding the Rules of the House for this procedure are decided without debate. The Rules of the House of Representatives apply to the procedure for bills or joint resolutions under this section, with decisions made without debate. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consideration of a bill or joint resolution is privileged and not debatable, with restrictions on amendments and reconsideration of the vote. The Senate debate on bills or joint resolutions under this section is limited to 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders. Debates on motions or appeals are restricted to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill's manager. The Senate debate on bills or joint resolutions under this section is limited to 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders. Debates on motions or appeals are restricted to 1 hour, with the minority leader controlling time in opposition if the bill manager is in favor. Amendments are prohibited, and motions to further limit debate or recommit the bill are not allowed. Amendments to bills or joint resolutions under this section are prohibited in both the House of Representatives and the Senate. Any budget authority proposed for rescission must be made available for obligation the day after the bill is defeated. The term 'appropriation Act' is defined as any general or special appropriation Act. The term 'appropriation Act' includes general or special appropriation Acts, supplemental, deficiency, or continuing appropriations. The continuity of a session of Congress is only broken by an adjournment sine die, with excluded days of adjournment over 3 days. The term 'appropriation Act' encompasses various types of appropriation Acts. The continuity of a session of Congress is interrupted only by an adjournment sine die, with excluded days of adjournment over 3 days. A special message transmitted during a Congress but not acted upon before adjournment will be considered transmitted on the first day of the next Congress. Amendments are made to Section 904 of the Act regarding rulemaking powers. The U.S.C. 621 note is amended by adding sections 1013 and 1018. Conforming amendments are made to sections 1011 and 1015 of the Act. Section 1015 of the Act is amended to include references to sections 1012, 1013, and 1014. Subsection (e)(2) is also modified to reflect these changes. Section 1016 of the Act is amended to include references to sections 1012, 1013, and 1014. Subpart B of title X of the Act is also updated with clerical amendments. The table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act is amended to redesignate sections 1013 through 1017 as sections 1014 through 1018, and to include a new item after section 1012. "Section 1013 allows expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions."
